messages: f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (19:07): anyone here know how to make a gridview auto generate the columns but still let you modify them?
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:10): or you can use the index of the column
c660158b3701e3e230c0ce136cacbe42 (19:10): If I create some c# code, compile in release mode, is there a way of debugging it. I have seen how to decompile it, just not how to debug it?
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:11): check it must be in the SDK
e930486dc1ff22e535dfd95d2b4ea972 (19:11): you can debug it with VS
e930486dc1ff22e535dfd95d2b4ea972 (19:11): just attach to the process
c660158b3701e3e230c0ce136cacbe42 (19:11): I ahve tried that, just crashes it, and I havent obsfucated my code or anything
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:11): it's called the Microsoft CLR Debugger
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:12): i used it to debug the VC# 2005 itself :P
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:13): me it's in the start > program > .NET Framework SDK > Tools
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:14): maybe you ain't got it also, i had to d/l it separately from my VC# express
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:15): damieng hm... even with the index?
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (19:15): if the grid view auto generates the columns they are not exposed as part of the public columns collection.
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:15): oh... i was sure i did used it
132e476d5f149efcd8a028b22510d8c3 (19:16): Sarkie you got the SDK in the start menu?
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (19:16): from MSDN: "Automatically generated bound column fields are not added to the Columns collection."
c660158b3701e3e230c0ce136cacbe42 (19:16): StaZ[work]: yeah but no GUIDebug, it is on 2005 its ok :) ill test it someother time

baa1ecff72c2b8ed32f4d30401cdc6ba (20:04): i have a grid view which is being populated by a datatable (created incode).  I have a column which contains a hyperlink - how can I get it to be rendered as a link?? putting html doesn't work
72d119e10c88e0430356c484d189ac4b (20:05): RandomThing, ok fine.. the printscreen key
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:06): Ben are you using autogeneratecolumns ?
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:09): i've been having similar problem
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:09): the standard gridview component doesn't let you access or modify the auto generated columns.
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:09): I've just, within the last couple of minutes, made a small gridview descendent that lets you do that
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:10): you shouldn't be trying to stick html into a text field
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:10): it will most likely be html encoded
baa1ecff72c2b8ed32f4d30401cdc6ba (20:10): that was a latest resort :)
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:10): gridview includes support for hyperlink columns.
baa1ecff72c2b8ed32f4d30401cdc6ba (20:11): but how can i tell it to be a hyperlink?
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:12): you first need to access the internal column collection
f4c73dd6ebee4426eb5e0e9a1909e589 (20:13): in your example it'll probably be easier to stop using autogeneratecolumns and add the columns to your gridview programmatically
b378ae477253895f9f9098809934b8c6 (20:13): when using a textbox how do i get the thing to ust have the text?
b378ae477253895f9f9098809934b8c6 (20:13): and not have a value of System.Windows.Forms.TextBox, Text:
